Note that formally, this is not a valid R bug report,  as `cluster` is a CRAN

on Fedora Linux,  when I repeatedly execute the final
```

```

of the functions that are called by the "top level" call,
even when, as here, the function is used wrongly (as here ..).

here, even though it's not about  R itself.

*[Bug 17279] parameter "amount" is badly explained for jitter()*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=17279>

Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
         Resolution|---                         |FIXED
             Status|CONFIRMED                   |CLOSED

--- Comment #9 from Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) ---
Thanks to Elin, and Rishabh et al, at the R Dev Day.

Note that both patch proposals do *not* describe the full subtlety of the
implementation, notably for say `jitter(c(9,9,Inf))`, `jitter(c(2,2))` or
`jitter(sqrt(-1:1))`;  all cases where you cannot use `max(x) - min(x)`
nor d := "smallest difference of unique values"  because these are zero or not
finite.

Of course, I'm grateful for the proposed reformulations which make the help
page more readable.

Given boundary cases like those above, I'm actually modifying the *definition*
of jitter() itself, notably dropping non-finite `x` values, not only when `z`
is computed but also when `d` is.

I do insist the mentioning of the original `jitter()` definition in S (which
Elin's patch did keep), namely a version of our `amount = 0` case.
Also, both patch proposals dropped "fuzz" I mentioned very much on purpose,
because that *is* handled with the subtle `round(..)` part in the code.

Given all the above: 
I continue to state that the function definition is a ""better"" documentation:
it also "shows" (or at least contains) what's happening in all boundary cases, 
which a "nicely readable" documentation typically glosses over..

--
I have committed my changes -- in the case of the help file copied from /
inspired by your proposals
to R-devel  svn rev 88827... and really want to close this now.

*[Bug 18851] could default argument for 'last' in substring() be changed?*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18851>

--- Comment #12 from Kevin Ushey (<mailto:kevinushey@gmail.com|kevinushey@gmail.com>) ---
It was mainly to accommodate Tomas's suggestions -- e.g. that we should treat
the default as `last = NULL`, and then ensure we preserve that information when
calling the underlying C API.

I guess as a smaller patch, we could default to `last = NULL` and then use

```
if(is.null(last)) last <- .Machine$integer.max
```

although we could (in theory) have a more efficient implementation of
`do_substr` if the API knew that we were only ever extracting suffixes.

I'll submit this final (super-minimal) version of the patch for consideration
too.

*[Bug 18353] assigning to hashtab via $<- 'corrupts' table*
https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18353

Elin Waring (elin.waring@gmail.com) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |elin.waring@gmail.com

--- Comment #3 from Elin Waring (elin.waring@gmail.com) ---
For me, direct assignment like this (especially a key with no value) doesn't
make sense.  The `sethash()` function provides access and ensures that it is
done properly. 

```
> object <- hashtab()
> sethash(object, "1", 2)
> object
<hashtable 0x1248c5760: count = 1, type = "identical">
> gethash(object, "1")
[1] 2


```

If the method is added, I think it should be to signal an error and then
preventing corruption of the hash table.
